means: 点（头）（以示同意、打招呼等）

sentence.Network_en: Those who fail incline to blame the world for their failure.
sentence.Network_cn: 那些失败者往往将他们的失败归咎于社会。

sentence.Network_en: The men had to slog up a steep muddy incline.
sentence.Network_cn: 人们只得在陡峭而泥泞的斜坡上艰难地行进。

sentence.Network_en: I incline to the view that we should take no action at this stage.
sentence.Network_cn: 我倾向于认为我们在这个阶段不应采取行动。

derivation.yuyuan_name: Middle English (originally in the sense 'bend (the head, the body, or oneself) towards something'); formerly also as encline): from Old French encliner, from Latin inclinare, from in- 'towards' + clinare 'to bend'

entry.def: If you incline to think or act in a particular way, or if something inclines you to it, you are likely to think or act in that way.

example.ex: I incline to the view that he is right.
example.tran: 我倾向于认为他是正确的。

example.ex: ...the factors which incline us towards particular beliefs...
example.tran: 使我们倾向于相信某些特定信仰的因素

entry.def: If you incline your head, you bend your neck so that your head is leaning forward.

example.ex: Jack inclined his head very slightly.

entry.def: An incline is land that slopes at an angle.

example.ex: He came to a halt at the edge of a steep incline.
example.tran: 他在一个陡坡边上停住了。

sentences.sentence: "the house was built on the side of the mountain"

means.word_mean: 2. an inclined surface or roadway that moves traffic from one level to another
1. have a tendency or disposition to do or be something; be inclined;

sentences.sentence: "She tends to be nervous before her lectures"

means.word_mean: 2. bend or turn (one's ear) towards a speaker in order to listen well;

sentences.sentence: "He inclined his ear to the wise old man"

means.word_mean: 3. lower or bend (the head or upper body), as in a nod or bow;

sentences.sentence: "She inclined her head to the student"

means.word_mean: 5. make receptive or willing towards an action or attitude or belief;

sentences.sentence: "Their language inclines us to believe them"

auth_sentence.content: When in doubt, they incline to the latter.
auth_sentence.res_content: When in doubt, they incline to the latter.
auth_sentence.res_content_con: When in doubt, they incline to the latter.

auth_sentence.content: His momentum rolled him over and over down the incline.
auth_sentence.res_content: His momentum rolled him over and over down the incline.
auth_sentence.res_content_con: His momentum rolled him over and over down the incline.

auth_sentence.content: Not far away was another tunnel - this time it started with a gentle incline so we could get inside.
auth_sentence.res_content: Not far away was another tunnel - this time it started with a gentle incline so we could get inside.
auth_sentence.res_content_con: Not far away was another tunnel - this time it started with a gentle incline so we could get inside.

stems_affixes.word_buile: dis不+inclined[[adj.倾向于,赞成的]]不兜摹鷄dj.不愿意的
incline[v.倾斜;偏向]+ed……的→adj.倾向于,赞成的
clin床+ic医学有关→n.门诊部, 临床
decline[v.倾斜;衰退]+ation表名词→n.衰退;下倾
in进入+clin倾斜,斜坡+e→进入斜→偏向,喜爱

Sentence.sentence: And though Hu Jintao and the rest of the Chinese leadership aren't inclined to lecture visiting Presidents, he might gently hint that Beijing is getting a little nervous about the value of the dollar-which has fallen 15% since March, in large part because of increasing fears that America's debt load is becoming unmanageable.
Compared with younger ones, older societies are less inclined to be innovative and take risks than younger ones.

means.word_mean: (使)倾斜, (使)偏向,（使）倾向于，有…的趋势 ~

sentences.en: He inclined forward so as to hear more clearly.
sentences.cn: 他向前倾斜着身体, 以便听得更清楚些。

sentences.en: I incline to take the opposite point of view.
His letter inclines me to think that it would be wrong for us to refuse his request.
sentences.cn: 他的信使我认为我们拒绝他的要求是错误的。

jushi.english: I incline to take the opposite point of view.
Older people incline to rise up early.
We are all inclined to mourn the passing of old institutions.
jushi.chinese: 我们常为失去古老的习俗而惋惜。
